flow.context: Anita Harcourt recently transitioned to an advisory role at Simply Steamboat / Resort Group as part of a 2024 executive succession plan that promoted Steve Frasier to CEO and Sara Koop to CFO. She likely held a senior leadership position before stepping back and retains deep institutional influence. Resort Group is a major Steamboat Springs PM operation — 90+ associations, 5,000+ units, 600+ nightly rentals, ~240 peak-season employees, running on TrackHS, heavy use of H-2B seasonal labor. They recently exited their Texas property to refocus entirely on Steamboat. Strongest connection: Sam skied Jackson Hole in January 2026 — skiing is the natural shared world with someone embedded in Steamboat's resort economy.

dial.label: DIAL
dial.note: Calling Anita Harcourt at Resort Group. Try (970) 879-8700 main line. She is in an advisory role — may not be in the office daily. Be ready for a gatekeeper or voicemail.

branches.label: Anita answers or transferred to her

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Anita — this is gonna sound a little random. I work with a few resort property managers in ski markets, and I'm a skier myself — was actually just out at Jackson Hole back in January. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around?
opener.note: Feet up on the desk energy. The skiing mention is real and natural — she's spent years in Steamboat's resort world. Don't rush past it. Smile.

branches.label: No, I haven't heard of you
Who is this? / What's this about?

heard_no.label: HEARD NO — TRANSITION TO PAIN
heard_no.say: Ha — I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call — I've been working with a few other resort property managers, couple of them in ski markets actually, and I was talking to one recently who's in a pretty similar spot to you guys at Resort Group. They're running a few hundred nightly rentals, seasonal staff cycling in and out, H-2B housekeepers — and the thing they kept running into was this: their cleaners were taking photos after every turn, uploading them into their PMS, but nobody actually had time to review all of them. So stuff would slip through — a gouge in a countertop, a missing set of towels, a broken drawer handle — and it wouldn't get caught until the next guest checked in and called the front desk on a Saturday night. Now you've got maintenance scrambling, a guest complaint, and an owner getting a call they shouldn't have to get.
heard_no.note: PAUSE here. Let the silence do the work. She'll either relate to the problem or push back. Do NOT jump to the solution yet.

branches.label: Yeah, that sounds familiar / we deal with that
I'm not really involved in that anymore
We've got that handled / not interested

heard_yes.label: HEARD YES — EXPLORE
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone like you. What did you hear?
heard_yes.note: Let her talk. Whatever she says, bridge into pain trigger or discovery. Don't correct anything — just listen and build on it.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again later this week? Maybe Thursday or Friday?
bad_timing.note: Don't push. Get a specific callback time. Two concrete days makes it easy to say yes.

branches.label: Just tell me quickly what this is about

reschedule_locked.label: RESCHEDULE CONFIRMED
reschedule_locked.say: Perfect — I've got that down. I'll try you then. Appreciate it, Anita.
reschedule_locked.note: Write down the exact day and time. Set a reminder. Call back ON TIME — this is a trust deposit.

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION FALLBACK
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call, I'll be straight with you. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out? And you can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit.
permission_fallback.note: Disarming honesty. Most people give you the 30 seconds when you own the awkwardness.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED — SPLIT
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and this just isn't interesting?
permission_rejected.note: Split the objection into two choices. This almost always gets them to reveal the real reason.

pain_trigger_short.label: PAIN TRIGGER — 30 SECOND VERSION
pain_trigger_short.say: So I work with resort property managers — and the thing I keep hearing, especially from folks running a high-volume turn operation like Resort Group, is that cleaners are taking photos after every turn, but nobody has the bandwidth to actually look at all of them. Stuff slips — damage, missing items, staging issues — and it doesn't surface until a guest calls the front desk. We built something that plugs right into Track and automatically analyzes those turnover photos so issues get flagged before the next guest walks in. Would you be open to taking a look when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue?
pain_trigger_short.note: This is the compressed version. Hit the pain, name Track to show you did your homework, one sentence on the solution, CTA. Then STOP TALKING and let her respond.

branches.label: I'm not really the right person for that
We already have something for that

one_sentence_solution.label: ONE-SENTENCE SOLUTION + CTA
one_sentence_solution.say: So we built an AI tool that plugs into Track — which I know you guys are running — and automatically analyzes the turnover photos your cleaners are already taking. Catches damage, missing items, staging issues before the next guest checks in. No workflow change on your team's end. Would you be open to taking a look when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue?
one_sentence_solution.note: Mentioning Track by name shows you've done your homework. One sentence on what it does, one on how it works, CTA. Don't oversell.

branches.label: Yeah, I'd be open to that
I'm not involved in ops anymore
We have a process for that already

warm_response.label: THEY'RE WARM — STOP PITCHING, ASK QUESTIONS
warm_response.say: That's great to hear. I'm curious — with the transition to Steve and Sara running things day to day, what does the inspection process look like right now across the nightly rental portfolio? Are your cleaners doing self-QA, or do you have separate inspectors checking behind them?
warm_response.note: Referencing the succession plan by name shows deep knowledge and signals this isn't a spray-and-pray call. She'll either engage on details or redirect you to someone current. Both outcomes are wins.

branches.label: You should really talk to someone else
We have inspectors / a system in place

discovery_deep.label: DEEP DISCOVERY
discovery_deep.say: That makes sense. And when something does slip through — like damage that doesn't get caught until a guest is already in the unit — how does that usually play out? Is it the front desk handling it live, or does it escalate up to the owner?
discovery_deep.note: You're mapping their pain chain: cleaner miss → front desk scramble → maintenance emergency → owner call → review risk. The more specific she gets, the stronger your meeting pitch will be.

branches.label: It's not a huge issue for us
That's really more of an Alan or Joseph question

reframe_value.label: REFRAME — OWNER TRUST ANGLE
reframe_value.say: Totally get that. One thing I hear from other resort managers is it's less about the big misses and more about the owner trust piece — being able to show owners documented proof that their unit was checked and guest-ready after every single turn. Especially with out-of-town owners who are trusting you with their investment. Is that something that comes up for you guys?
reframe_value.note: Joe Cashen publicly said owners 'trust us with the keys to their dream.' The asset-protection and owner-retention angle resonates when the operational pain doesn't land.

branches.label: Yeah, that's a real thing for us
We handle that through our owner portal

bridge_to_meeting.label: BRIDGE TO MEETING
bridge_to_meeting.say: This is really helpful context. I think it'd be worth showing you what we've built — it's pretty visual and a lot easier to see than explain on a cold call. If nothing else, I could walk you through what a few other resort PMs in ski markets are doing with their turnover photos. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends. Would you be open to 20 minutes next week?
bridge_to_meeting.note: The offer of value: the meeting is worth their time even if they never buy. Pick a specific day next.

branches.label: You should loop in someone else too

not_my_role.label: NOT MY ROLE — ADVISORY REDIRECT
not_my_role.say: Totally makes sense — I know you've moved into more of an advisory capacity with the transition. I'd love to get in front of the right person. Who on the team right now would own something like inspection workflow or turnover quality? Would that be more of an Alan Koermer conversation, or someone else?
not_my_role.note: Dropping Alan's name shows deep homework and makes it easy for her to confirm or redirect. Don't push her to take the meeting herself — the referral is the win here.

branches.label: Gives another name or suggests ops/housekeeping
Not sure / just email the office

referral_ask.label: REFERRAL ASK
referral_ask.say: That'd be awesome. Who would be the best person to talk to about this? I want to make sure I'm not wasting the wrong person's time.
referral_ask.note: Simple and direct. Let her name the person. If she's vague, offer names from your research to make it easy for her.

referral_prompt.label: PROMPT FOR SPECIFIC NAME
referral_prompt.say: No worries. Would it be more of an operations person — like whoever runs housekeeping or the front office day to day? Or would this be a Steve Frasier-level decision?
referral_prompt.note: Give her two altitude options. She'll pick one or offer a third name. You know Joseph Pierce runs housekeeping and Daniel Infante runs front office — use those names if she's vague.

referral_alan.label: REFERRAL — ALAN KOERMER
referral_alan.say: Alan — perfect. I actually have his info. Would it help if I mentioned you pointed me his way, or would you rather I just reach out cold?
referral_alan.note: Getting permission to name-drop Anita is gold. It turns the next call from cold to warm. Alan was VP of Ops, now SVP — he's the ideal operational decision-maker.

branches.label: Just reach out on your own

referral_steve.label: REFERRAL — STEVE FRASIER
referral_steve.say: Steve — got it. Would you be okay if I mentioned you suggested I reach out? That'd go a long way coming from you.
referral_steve.note: Steve is the new CEO as of 2024. A referral from Anita, his predecessor or co-advisor, carries enormous weight. This is the highest-value outcome of this call.

branches.label: Just reach out on your own

referral_ops.label: REFERRAL — OPS / HOUSEKEEPING
referral_ops.say: That makes total sense — the housekeeping side is usually where this hits hardest. Do you have a name for who runs that? I've seen Joseph Pierce's name come up as the housekeeping director — is he still the right person?
referral_ops.note: Confirm the name. If she corrects you or gives a different name, even better — you've got fresh intel that no database has.

referral_new_name.label: REFERRAL — NEW NAME
referral_new_name.say: Perfect — and what's their title? I just want to make sure I put something relevant together so it actually lands when I reach out. And would it be cool to mention you pointed me their way?
referral_new_name.note: Get the full name, title, and permission to name-drop. Write it ALL down immediately.

referral_genevieve.label: FALLBACK — OFFICE / GENEVIEVE
referral_genevieve.say: Got it — I'll reach out through the main office. I think Genevieve Murphy handles some of the inbound over there. Anita, really appreciate your time on this — enjoy the rest of the season up there.
referral_genevieve.note: Mentioning Genevieve by name shows you know the org even if Anita doesn't give you a direct referral. You still got intel. Follow up with Genevieve at (970) 875-2845.

referral_thanks.label: REFERRAL LOCKED — CLOSE WARM
referral_thanks.say: That's incredibly helpful — I'll put something tailored together for them so it's not just another generic pitch. Really appreciate you taking my call, Anita. Enjoy the rest of the season up there.
referral_thanks.note: You got the referral. STOP SELLING. Don't add anything. The ski-season close is warm and specific to her world. Send your outreach to the referral within 24 hours while Anita's name is still warm.

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: I totally get it — I should have assumed you'd be all set. Otherwise you probably would have reached out to us. Just so nobody from my team cold calls you again — is it that this isn't really a problem you're focused on right now, or is it more that you just hate cold calls?
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first — surprise her by not pushing back. Then split the objection. Most people soften once you acknowledge their position without fighting it.

branches.label: Hate cold calls / just the interruption
Not focused on this / not my area

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with 600-plus nightly rentals across the brands, you'd have to have something dialed in. Is it that you're fully covered and happy with how it's working, or is it more that switching anything right now — especially with the leadership transition — would just be a headache?
objection_have_process.note: Referencing their scale (600+ nightly rentals) and the succession plan validates the objection and shows you understand their world. The split separates satisfaction from switching cost.

branches.label: We're happy with what we have
Switching would be a headache / timing
It's more that I'm not the decision-maker

competitive_curiosity.label: COMPETITIVE — WHAT ARE THEY USING
competitive_curiosity.say: Totally respect that. Out of curiosity — are you guys using a dedicated inspection platform for that, or is it more of a built-in workflow inside Track? I ask because a lot of the resort PMs I talk to have something, but the actual photo review piece is still pretty manual.
competitive_curiosity.note: This is intel gathering. Whatever she says helps you tailor the next touch or the approach to whoever she refers you to. If she mentions Breezeway, note it — Moving Mountains nearby uses it.

branches.label: We use Breezeway / a dedicated tool
I don't know the details anymore

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Especially with the refocus on Steamboat and the leadership transition — I'm sure every dollar is being watched closely right now. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that budget this cycle is completely locked, or is it more that anything new has to go through a pretty rigorous approval process with the new leadership?
objection_no_budget.note: Reference the strategic refocus (exiting Casa Del Mar, consolidating on Steamboat) and the CEO transition to show you understand their moment. The split separates 'no money' from 'hard process.'

test_drive_pitch.label: TEST DRIVE — SELL THE FUTURE MEETING
test_drive_pitch.say: Look — you're probably not buying anything right now, and I totally respect that. But when the timing does make sense, the people who move fastest are the ones who already know what's out there. Would you be open to just taking a look — not to buy anything, but so you know it exists? If nothing else, I can walk you through what other resort PMs in ski markets are doing with their turnover photos. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends.
test_drive_pitch.note: You're selling the meeting, not the product. Low pressure. The 'steal some ideas' line works because it makes the meeting valuable even if they never buy.

branches.label: You should talk to someone else on the team

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Awesome. I've got next week pulled up — how does Tuesday or Wednesday look for you? I'm flexible on time.
book_meeting.note: Pick two specific days. Lock the time NOW. Don't leave it vague or say 'I'll send you some times.' If she wants to include someone else, that's even better — get the name.

branches.label: Let me check and get back to you
Include someone else on the call too

lock_time.label: LOCK THE TIME
lock_time.say: Perfect — I'll send over a calendar invite right now so it's locked in. It'll come from sam@rapideye.ai. Really appreciate you taking my call, Anita. Talk soon.
lock_time.note: Send the calendar invite IMMEDIATELY while still on the phone. Then STOP SELLING. Get off the call. Don't add any more details or caveats.

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair. One quick question before I do — what would be most helpful to include so it's not just another generic pitch sitting in your inbox? Is it more the technical side of how it works with Track, or more the business case around what other resort PMs are seeing in terms of results?
send_email.note: This question does two things: tailors your follow-up AND keeps the conversation going another 30 seconds. Whatever she says, include it. Always put a specific meeting time suggestion in the email.

email_confirm.label: EMAIL CONFIRMED — GET ADDRESS
email_confirm.say: Got it — I'll send that over today. What's the best email for you? And I'll toss a couple time options in there in case you want to hop on a quick call after you've had a chance to look it over. Appreciate your time, Anita.
email_confirm.note: Get her direct email address. The follow-up email MUST include: what she asked for, a personalized line referencing this conversation, and two specific time options for a call. Send it within the hour.

gatekeeper.label: GATEKEEPER — SLIDE BY
gatekeeper.say: Hey — could you get me through to Anita? It's Sam.
gatekeeper.note: Bare minimum info. Say it like you know her. First names only for both of you. Don't volunteer anything else.

branches.label: She's not available / not in today

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — ADD CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah — I work with a few other resort property managers in ski markets. Would you mind letting her know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Still no pitch. Just enough context to sound legitimate and relevant. End with a redirect question so you stay in control.

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: RapidEye — we help a couple other property management companies with their inspection workflows. I sent her a note and was just following up. Would you mind giving her a heads up?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: Third layer. If they're still blocking after this, pivot to voicemail or ask for a different contact. Don't get adversarial with the gatekeeper.

branches.label: She's not the right person for that

gatekeeper_voicemail.label: GATEKEEPER — LEAVE MESSAGE OR PIVOT
gatekeeper_voicemail.say: Sure — just let her know Sam Parks called from RapidEye. She can reach me at my direct line. And actually — who on the team handles the day-to-day operations side? Housekeeping, inspections, that kind of thing?
gatekeeper_voicemail.note: Leave the message, then immediately pivot to getting a referral name from the gatekeeper. You might get Alan Koermer, Joseph Pierce, or Daniel Infante confirmed — or a name you don't have yet.

branches.label: Gives a name or suggests someone
I don't know / try back later

gatekeeper_redirect.label: GATEKEEPER — GET TRANSFERRED
gatekeeper_redirect.say: Perfect — would you be able to transfer me over to them? Or what's the best direct number to reach them?
gatekeeper_redirect.note: Get the transfer or the direct line. If transferred, you're starting fresh with a new person — adapt the opener with their name. If you get a number, write it down and call immediately.

branches.label: Gives a phone number or email

voicemail.label: VOICEMAIL
voicemail.say: Hey Anita — it's Sam Parks with RapidEye. I work with a few resort property managers in ski markets on their inspection workflows, and I wanted to run something by you that's relevant to what you guys are doing at Resort Group. I'll try you again later this week — or you can grab me at sam@rapideye.ai. Talk soon.
voicemail.note: Keep it under 20 seconds. Sound like a peer, not a salesperson. Don't pitch. Don't explain what RapidEye does. The goal is just name recognition so the next call or email isn't fully cold. Try calling back at a different time of day.

end_graceful.label: END — GRACEFUL EXIT
end_graceful.say: Totally understand. If anything changes, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks at RapidEye. Appreciate your time, Anita. Enjoy the rest of the season up there.
end_graceful.note: Don't burn the bridge. The ski-season close is warm and specific to her world. She may circle back, or you'll reach her through Alan, Steve, or Joseph on a separate call. Log everything she said for next time.
